history.content:
When I took CS61B with Professor Hilfinger in Fall 16, the exams did not count for very much of our grade (8.5% for each midterm, 23% for the final).

In terms of how to do well on the exams, I would say that most of the questions do not try to trick you, but test your knowledge on fundamentals.  I think it's worth dividing time equally between reviewing notes/taking practice times, leaning towards the latter if you are pressed for time.

It's certainly possible to get near 100% on all of the projects if you put the time into them and make them your priority when they are due.  

Though I can't speak for those who took CS61B with Professor Hug, I found 61B with Professor Hilfinger extremely rewarding and feel that I came away prepared for future classes and a better programmer.  11/10 would recommend.

children.subject: Thanks so much for your fast reply! I heard averages for tests are really low. Is there any knowledge I could learn prior to the course starting to ensure I do well on the exams? I need to do pretty well in 61B in order to declare..

I wouldn't worry at all. 61B with Hilfinger is actually relatively easy (compared to what I was expecting). As the student answer said, exams are not worth a whole lot. Also if you try hard and put in as much effort as you can, getting 100% on all the projects is very doable, in which case you can get like 60% on the exams and get an A (yep a solid A). According to Berkeleytime, in Fall 2016, around 40% of the class got solid As.

best preparation: Have a lot of time on your hands :)
on a side note, take a look at berkeley time for average grades and the distributions (hint: a lot of people get A's)
hilfinger weights tests very lightly so as long as you concentrate, put in the work, and don't slip on projects you should be fine with him

Took it with Hilfinger in Fall 2015 as well and had almost the same experience as the poster above. IIRC, I walked into the final needing something like a 7/46 to get an A. Start the projects early, don't slack, and the A/A+ is pretty straightforward.

That being said, I do feel like I learnt very little about data structures, at least compared to my friends who took it with Hug. On the plus side, the projects are genuinely phenomenal and I became a much, much better programmer having taken 61B with Hilfinger (perhaps even more than those same friends who took it with Hug).

I took 61B Fall 2015 with Hilfinger. Going into the final, I had nearly 10% extra credit in the class, while midterms were only 8.5% each. EC came from surveys and projects. With that, I only needed a 20% to get an A, and a 50% to get an A+. I LOVED the projects in 61B, and I think that you're able to get perfect scores on them with enough effort. Midterms are hard (I didn't get that much above average on them), but don't count for much.

Definitely one of my favorite classes at Berkeley.

I can't speak for Hilfinger's exams as I took the course with Hug, but for me I felt that 61B exams were more straightforward that 61A exams. Especially on the later exams there were more mechanical type questions that were more knowledge based and less tricky (e.g. carrying out an algorithm on a graph, runtime questions, etc). That being said there will definitely be parts of the exam that are tricky. With practice and diligent studying I found the 61B exams to be better than 61A exams and ended up doing better in the class (B+ vs A). 

Just some tips that I found helpful: Always try to stay up to date on lecture and best way to do this is to actually attend lecture, always go to discussion, enroll in a CSM section, start projects early and dedicate a lot of time to them, do all extra credit/gold points opportunities if they are available, study hard and ask questions when you have them to reinforce your learning.

Best of luck!

For those who say 61B exams do not try to trick you, do you guys think 61a exams were tricky (not necessarily Prof Hilfinger) I found it very tricky and in some questions I felt like they were testing more trickiness than actual programming. I enjoyed programming in 61a  but I dont know how I would do in a harder class with the same level of trickiness.
Honestly a very rewarding class if you dedicate a good time to building the projects, homework, and labs.

history.content:
For those who have taken CS61B with Prof. Hilfinger and did well in the exams, could you please give me tips on how I can fully prepare?

Also, is it reasonable to assume that I can aim for 100% on projects? 

I really appreciate all advice!! :)
history.subject: [ADVICE] CS61B with Prof. Hilfinger Fall 17
